abstract.p: A delivery system (100) for delivering a collapsible prosthetic heart valve includes a body (120) extending in a longitudinal direction and a sheath (130) slidable relative to the body. A compartment (155) is defined inside the sheath and is adapted to receive the collapsible prosthetic heart valve in a collapsed condition. The system includes an articulating joint having a first portion operatively connected to the compartment and a second portion operatively connected to the body. The first portion is pivotable relative to the second position so as to pivot the sheath from a first orientation extending in the longitudinal direction to a second orientation extending transverse to the longitudinal direction.

Un compartiment (155) est défini à l'intérieur de la gaine et conçu pour recevoir la valvule cardiaque prothétique pliable dans un état plié. Le système comprend un articulation ayant une première partie reliée fonctionnelle au compartiment et une seconde partie reliée fonctionnelle au corps. La première partie peut pivoter par rapport à la seconde position, afin de faire pivoter la gaine à partir d'une première orientation s'étendant dans la direction longitudinale vers une seconde orientation s'étendant en diagonale par rapport à la direction longitudinale.

description.p: TRANS PΪCAL PASSIVE ARTICULATION DELIVERY SYSTEM DESIGN
BACKGROUND OF THE INVENTION

[0001] The present invention is related to prosthetic heart valve replacement , and more particularly to devices, systems, and methods for t sanscafcheter delivery of collapsible prosthetic heart valves .

[0002] Prosthetic heart valves that are collapsible to a rela ively small circumferential size can be delivered into a patient less invasively than v lves that are not collapsible. For exam l , a collapsible valve ma be delivered into a patient, via a tube-like delivery apparatus such as a catheter, a trocar, a laparoscopic instrument, or the like. This coilapsibility can avoid the need for a more invasive procedure such as full open-chest, open-heart surgery.

[0003] Collapsible prosthetic, heart valves typically take the form of a valve structure mounted on a stent. There are two types of stents OP, which the valves structures are ordinarily mounted: a self-expanding stent and a balloon- expandable stent. To place such v lves into a delivery apparatus and ultimately into a patient., the valve must first be collapsed cr crimped o reduce its circumferential size. These collapsible and re-expandable prosthetic heart valves can then be implanted transapically or percu taneous1 y through the arterial system, such as through the femo al artery.

[0004] When a collapsed prosthetic, valve has reached the desired impl nt site in the patient {e.g.., at or near the smniLus of the patient's heart valve that is to be replaced by the prosthetic v lve } , the prosthetic valve can be deployed or released from the delivery apparatus and re-expanded to full operating size , Foi: balloon-expandable valves, this generally involves releasing the entire valve, assuring its proper location, and then expanding a balloon positioned within the valve stent. For self-expanding valves, on the other hand,
the stent automatically begins to expand as the sheath covering the vaive is withdrawn .

[0005] In conventional delivery systems for self-expanding aortic valves , for example, after the delivery system has been positioned for deployment, the annul-as end of tine valve is typically unsheathed and expanded first, while the aortic end of the valve remains sheathed. Once the annulus end of the valve has expanded, it may be determined that the valve needs to be repositioned in the patient's aortic annulus. To accomplish this, a user (such as a surgeon or an inter ventional cardiologist) typically resheathes the annulus end of the valve, so that the valve can be repositioned while in a collapsed state . After the valve has been repos ioned, the user can again release the valve.

[0006] As stated above, collapsible prosthetic heart valves may be delivered to the valve annulus, and particularly the aortic vaive annulus, either tra rcsfamorally or transapicaliy, as well as by other percutaneous procedures . In transferaorai valve implantation, the collapsible prosthetic heart valve is introduced, through the femoral artery and is ult imately delivered in a retrograde manner through the aortic arch to the native aortic valve annulus. In transapical vaive implantation, the collapsible prosthetic heart valve is delivered in an antegrade fashion through the apex of the heart to the native aortic valve annulus.

[00Q7] I transapical valve implantation, it would be preferable if the axis of the entry point at the apex of the heart was coaxial with the axis of the annulus of the aortic: heart valve. This would allow a straight transapical valve delivery device to enter the left ventricle through the apex of the heart arid move in a straight line directly through the center of the annulus area of the aortic heart vaive. However, in patients with diseased hearts and heart valves, there can be a. mismatch of up to 30 or 40 degrees between the apical and
annular axes. Moreover, tissue structures within the heart may interfere with a straight path from the a es of the heart to the center of the aortic valve annulus . These structural issues can acid addi ional difficulty to the process of correctly a igning a prosthetic heart valve at the sire of implantation .

[0008] Despite the various improvement s that have been made to the collapsible prosthetic heart valve delivery process, con entionsi delivery devices, systems, and methods suffer from some shortcomi ngs . For example, prosthetic valve delivery devices have not yet fully addressed patient specific mismatches between the apical and annular axes or the heart or the presence of interfering tissue structures .

[0009] There therefore is a need for further improvements to the devices, systems, and methods for transcatheter delivery of collapsible prosthetic heart valves, arid in particular, sei f-expanding prosthetic heart valves. Among other advan ages, the present invention may address one or more of: these needs.
BRIEF SUMMARY OF THE INVENTION

[00X03 The present disclosure relates to delivery systems or delivering a medical device to an implantation site in a patient, such as a collapsible prosthetic heart valve. In one embodiment, a delivery system includes a body extending in a longitudinal direction. A sheath is siidabie relative to the body, and a compartment is defined inside the sheath and is adapted to receive the medical device in an assembled condition. The system also includes an articulating joint having a first portion opersti eiy connected bo the sheath and a second portion operativsly connected to the body. The first: portion is pivotable relative to the second portion so as to pivot the sheath from a first orientation ex-tending in the longitudinal direction to a second, orientation extending transverse i:o the longitudinal direction. The articulating
joint can include a ball and a socket. The system can further include a restrictive sheath slidable relative to the ar icula ing joint between a lock position and a release position. The restrictive sheath, when in the lock position, at least partially ci cumsc ibes the articulating joint. When in the release position, the restrictive sheath at most partial iy circumscribes the articulating joint. The restrictive sheath can include a slot; having with a width less than the width of the first portion of the articula ng joint . The first por ion of the articulating joint may be configured to pivot through the slot in a single plane when the restrictive sheath is in the release position. The restrictive sheath may include proximal and distal portions, and the distal portion may be proximal to the first portion of the articulating joint when the restrictive sheath is in the release position. In this release position, the first, portion of the articulating joint may be configured to pivot in any plane relative to the second portion of the articulating joint .

[0011] The restrictive sheath of the delivery system may also be rotatahie about an axis extending in the longitudinal direction . The restrictive sheath ina also be operably connected to a retraction mechanise at a proximal end of the delivery system. The retraction mechanism can be a wheel. The restrictive sheath may also include visual indicia of location, such as line markings or fluoroscopic markings. The delivery system may further include a locking feature configured to compress the socket toward the ball. The locking feature can be a locking sheath slidable between a lock condi ion surrounding a largest cross -section of the socket and a release condition not surrounding the largest cross -section of the socket. The locking feature can alternately be a chuck.

DETAILED DESCRIPTION

[0022] As used herein, the terms "proximal" and "distal" are to be taken, as relative to a user" (e.g. , a surgeon or an interventional cardiologist) of the disclosed delivery
devices, "Proximal" is to be understood as relatively close to the user arid "distal" is to be understood as relatively farther wa from the user,

0023] FIGS. 1-3 illustrate a delivery system 100 for transapical 1 delivering any suitable collapsible prosthetic heart, valve into a patient. Collapsible and re -expandable prosthetic heart valve;;; are more fully described in U.S. Patent Application Publication No. 2011/0098800, the entire disclosure of which is hereby incorporated by reference herein. Delivery system 100 gene lly includes a njanifold 110, a tubular shaft or valve support structure 120, a distal sheath 130, a proximal sheath 170, and an atraumatic tip 140.

[0024] Shaft 120 has a first retainer 165 fixedly connected to its proxima 1 end and a second retainer 160 fixedly connec d to its distal end so as to define a valve -recei ing compartment 155 of a fixed dimension between the retainer£3. Compar ment 155 is sized to receive a collapsible pros hetic heart valve 150 an assecctbied condition. In that regard, retainer 160 may have a plurality of notches or pockets for receiving retention membe s (not shown) on prosthetic valve 150 so as to hold the aortic end of the heart valve in assembled relationship with delivery system 100. Transcatheter aortic valve delivery systems implementing retainers a e more fully described in U.S. Patent Publication No. 2012/0078350, the entire disclosure of which is hereby incorporated by reference herein.

E 0025 J Proximal sheath 170 extends from a handle (not shown) to the fixed retainer 165, A condui 132 extends through proximal sheath 170 to atraumatic tip 140, passing slidabiy through the lumen of shaft 120. At its proximal end, conduit 132 may be connected to the handle or may protrude therefrom for manipulation by the user of delivery system 100. The distal sheath 130 is connected to the atraumatic tip 140 so that sliding movement of conduit 132 r sults in a
corresponding sliding movement of the distal sheath. Thar is, as conduit: 132 is slid distally relative to shaft 120 , distal sheath 130 is moved toward an open position uncovering the valve --receivi ng compartment 155 for deployment oi: the prosthetic heart valve 150, and as condui 132 is slid proxiraally relative to shaft 120, the distal sheath is moved toward a closed position covering the valve-re'celving compartment and maintaining the prosthetic hear:;:, valve in a collapsed condition . A proximal edge 175 of distal sheath 130 abuts retainer 165 when the distal sheath is in the closed position fully covering compartment 155. The proximal edge 175 of distal sheath 130 is spaced apart from, retainer 165 when compartment 155 is at least partially uncovered, as shown in FIG. 3.

[0026] Conduit .132 is flexible enough to bend upon introduction or withdrawal from the body, as well as during articulation of the delivery system 100, However, conduit 132 retains enough stiffness to transmit force, such as when the conduit is slid distally, pushing the distal sheath 130 distally. Conduit 132 may have a lumen extending along its entire length for receiving a guide wire (not shown} . The guide wire may extend through conduit 132 and out: from delivery system 100 through, a bore (not shown) extending longitudinally throug atraumatic tip 140.

[0027 ] Referring to FIG. 4A, a transapical delivery system 100' is shown according to an embodiment of the invention. The delivery system 100* is generally similar to delivery system 100 described above, and further includes an articulation, mechar; ism 200.

[0028] FIG. B shows a. magnified view of articulation mechan sm 200 with the body of delivery system 100' shown as partially transparent so that the components of the articulation mechan sm can be more easily seen, The articulation mechanism 200 includes ar; articulating joint 220
disposed proximal iy oil retainer 165. Referring to the detailed views in FIGS. 5A-D, the articulating joint 220 has a bail and socket configuration, allowing 36G degrees of rotation. More particul rl , joint 220 has a first portion 225 including a generally cylindrical body 260 with a hemi sphe ioal head or "hall" 230 on one end thereof . The ball 230 m be connected to the body 260 by a neck portion 231 which Ray be sinailer in cross-section than the body. The other end of body 260 raay be connected to retainer 165. A second or socket portion 235 of joint 220 ma be press fit in the end of proximal sheath 170. A spherical end 240 of socket portion 235 has a shape thai: is complementary to ball 230 so as to define a su ace against which the ball may pivot , Spherical end 240 raay be sized and shaped to receive bail 230 in a snap it or compression fit engagement to ensure that bail 230 .is always in contact with the pivot: surface. Spherical end 240 may also include one or more slots 245 extending par ially or folly th ough the diameter of the spherical end. The slots 245 may provide a level of sxpa ndab5.1 i ty to the spherical end 240. This expandability may, for example, ease the insertion of ball- 230 into spherical end 240 during assembly. The slots 245 may also provide spherical end 240 with a degree of compressibility, the purpose of which will become evident from the description below. The slots 245 may also serve other functions, the purpose of which will become evident from the description below. A bore 270 extending longitudinally through first portion 225 and socket, portion 235 is sized to slidably receive conduit 132 therethrough.

[0023] A rest ictive sheath 210 is slidably ssembled over joint 220 so as to be movable between a lock position and a release position. Sheath 210 has a generally cylindrical struc ure with a U-shaped slot 250 formed in e cylindrical wall so as to extend longitudinally fcom the distal end. thereof . The U-shaped slo 250 defines in sheath 210 a closed
portion 255 {i , e . , the portion without the U-shaped slot) and a partially open portion 265 {i.e., the portion with the U-shaped slot.) The widc of slot 250 is larger han the widest, diameter of the body 260 of first portion 225, allowing the body to pass through the slot in the restric ive sheath 210 when the first portion pivots . When moved to the lock position, the closed portion 255 of sheath 210 covers at least a substantial portion of both first portion 225 and socket portion 2.35, thereby preventing ball. 230 from pivoting against spherical end 240. In this look position, the first portion 225 of the articulating joint 220 is prevented from pivoting r lative to the socket portion 235, and the distal sheath 130 is locked in axial alignment with the longitudinal axis of the proximal sheat 170. In the release position, sheath 210 is inoved away from the first portion 225 until the slot 250 exposes the entirety of body 260, thereby enabli g the fiirst portion to pivot relati e to the socket portion 235. FIGS. 5A--5D show sheath 210 in the release position and the first portion 225 in different stages of a iculation rela ive to the socket portion 235. When the first portion 225 is pivoted relative to the socket portion 235, the distal s eath 130 will be oriented at an angle transverse to the longitudinal azis of the proximal shea h 170. The fi st portion 225 is free to ivot in a single plane through the slot 250 of t e rest ictive sheath 210, preferably through an angle of about 0° to about: 45* relative to t e longitudinal axis of the proximal sheath 170. Benefits of the pivoting motion are ex lained more fully below in the description of the su gical use of the delivery system 100' .

[0030] In addition to being slidable relative to joint 220, the restrictive sheath 210 may also be rota table about its longitudinal axi . A user can rotate e restrictive shea;:b. 210 through an angle of 360° about its longitudinal axis, changing the posi ion of slot 250 and, hence, the direction or
plane in which the first portion 225 of joint 220 may pivot. This allows the user to control which plans the foody 260 and, therefore, the distal sheath 130, raay pivot: in relation to the longitudinal ax i s of the proximal sheath 170, When in the lock position, the restrictive sheath 210 is positioned within the distal sheath 130 (which is also in the closed position) , This co figuration allows the outer surface of the delivery system 100 * to maintain a relatively flush surface near the point: of contact between the restrictive sheath 210 and the distal sheath 130. A explained below, this configuration reduces the like ihood of blood leakage during insertion of the delivery sys em 100' through the apex of the heart, The proximal end of the restrictive sheath 210 may be opera i e.l.y connected to a mechanism (cot shown) outside the patient: to enable the restric ive sheath to be .retracted to the release position and advanced to the lock position. For example, the restrictive sheath 210 can extend, proxiroaliy to a handle (not shown) of the delivery system 100 ' such that the user- can manually pull or push the restrictive sheath as desired between the lock and release positions . I a preferred embodiment, the restrictive s eath 210 may be operativeiy connected, o a wheel mechanism (not shown) near the handle of the delivery system 1001 to provide the operator wi h fine control over the movement of the restrictive sheath between the lock arid release positions. The restrictive sheath 210 may further include indicia tha: are visible using an imaging technique, such as fluoroscopy, to indicate the position of the restric ive sheath within the patient 's heart . Alternatively, the delivery system 100 ' may include indicia that remain outside of the patient's body, but that are operativeiy connected to restrictive sheath 210 so as to provide an indication of its position within the hear .

[0031] When practicing an mbodime t of the invention, a collapsible prosthetic heart valve 150 is collapsed around the
shaft 120 of a delivery system 1001 and held in place s-! compartment 155 by moving the distal sheath 130 to the closed position. The distal end of the delivery system 100' is advanced through an incision in the apex of the hea t using conven ional techniques well known in the art. The procedure may be performed on a beating heart, using a purse string suture on the incision through which the delivery s stem 100' is advanced. The purse string suture allows the surgeon to insert the delivery system 100 ! into the heart through the incision, and tighten the incision around the delivery device by pulling the suture, allowing for a better seal between the heart, tissue and the delivery device. Because blood may be flowing through the heart daring the procedure, it is preferable for the restr ctive sheath 210 to be flush with the remainder of the body of the device to minimize any leakage when the articulation mechanism 200 passes into or out from the heart . Further, the restrictive sheath 210 preferably is in the lock position during insertion and withdrawal of t he delivery system 100 ' to provide stability to the delivery system at the location of the articulation mechanism 200 and to ensure that articulation of the joint 220 does not occur prema f urel .

[0032] Once the articulation mechanism 200 has passed into the heart, which may be indicated by visual, fluoroscopic or other markings on or connected to the restrictive sheath 210, the operator may choose to change the orientation of the distal sheath 130 to facilitate vale placement . To do so, the operator may retract the restrictive sheath 210 to the release position, allowing articulation of joint 220. Joint 220 may provide up to 360 degrees of a ticulation once the restrictive sheath 210 is in the release position . The articulation of joint 220 causes the dis al end of the delivery system 100·, including the distal sheath 130, to pivot with respect to the longitudinal axis of the proximal sheath 170. This pivoting
provides the operator the afoi 1 i ty to mere precisely align the distal sheath 130 of the delivery system 100' with the native valve annul us, particularly when there is a significant mismatch between the apical and annular axes or interfering tissue structures, as described above. For example, if the apical and annular axes are not coaxial, it would be difficult or impossible to maintain the proximal end of an unbending delivery device coaxial with the entry point at: the apex of the heart while simultaneously having the distal end of the delivery device containing the valve coaxial with the annulus in which the valve is to be deployed. The articula ion joint 220 makes this possible, even when, there is significant mismatch between the axis of he apex and the axis of the native valve annulus. Once the operator is satisfied that the distal sheath 130, and thus the prosthetic heart valve 150, is properly aligned with the native valve annuius, the heart valve may be deployed as described above and as is well known in the art. Prior to withdrawal of the delivery system .100' from the heart, the operator may advance the restrictive sheath 210 to the lock position to both. ensure a smooth outer su f ce of the device arid provide stability at the articulation joint 22G. Optionally, the proper location of the restrictive sheath 210 may be confirmed with visual indicia, such as visual or: fluoroscopic markers, and then the delivery system 100' may be removed from the patient's heart.

[0033] FIGS. 62V-B show an articulation mechanism 300 in accordance with an alternate embodl ment . This embodiment is simi ar to articulation mechanism 200 described above, and includes an articulating joint 320 having a first portion 325 and. a second or socket portion 335, and a restrictive sheath 310. In articulation mechanism 300, however, the restrictive; sheath 310 does not have a U-shaped slot. When in the release position shown in FIG. SB, the entirety of restrictive sheath 310 is proximal of the first portion 325, and therefore does
not rest ict the articulating joint 320 from pivoting in any plane to orient the distal s eath .130 at a transverse angle to the longitudinal axis of the p oximal sheath 170. The first portion 325 may pivot through an angle of about 0* to about 45° relative to the longitudinal axis of the proximal sheath 170. When in the lock position shown in FIG. 6A, the restrictive sheath 310 covers at least: a substantial portion of both the first: portion 325 and the socket portion 33 S, there y preventing these portions from pivoting relative to one another and locking the distal sheath 130 in axial alignment w th the longitudinal axis of the proximal sheath 170.

[ 0034] An articulation mechanism 400 in accordance with yet: a further embodi ent is shown in FIG. 7. This embodiment is similar to articulation mecha isms 200 and 300 described above, and includes an articulating oint 420 having a f rst portion 425 and a second or socket portion 435, as we 1 as a restrictive sheath 410. Articulation mechanism 400 further includes a chuck or locking sheath 450 for locking the articulating joint 420 at a selected ngle . As described above, once inside, the heart, the res ictive sheath 410 may be retracted to i: he release position to allow the joint 420, as well as the distal sheath 130 of the deli ery system 100', to articulate. Once the distal sheath 130 is at a desired angle, for example a angle that aligns the distal sheath coaxiaily with the site of valve implantation, it may be desirable to lock the articulation joint 420 at the selected angle . If the joint 420 is not locked, movement of the delivery system 100 ' during the process of deploying the prosthetic valve may cause the distal sheath 130 to move relative to the proximal sheath 170 so that it is no longer in the desired orientation. A locking feature in the nature of locking sheath 450 can prevent or at least minimize such ■movements .
[00351 Locking sheath 450 may be in the form of a sheath extending from the proximal end of t he delivery system 100 ' to he oint 420, At its proximal end, locking sheath 450 may be connected to a handle (not shown] or may protrude therefrom for manipulation by the user of the delivery s stem 100'♦ The locking sheath 450 may e positioned within the lumen of the restrictive sheath 410, and is moveable between a lock position and an unlock position . When the distal sheath 130 has been oriented at the desired angle, the locking sheath 450 ma be advanced past the distal end of the restrictive sheath 410 and around the spherical end 440 of the socket portion 435 to the lock position (as s own in FIG, 7} « The inner diameter of the locking sheath 450 may be smaller than the largest diameter of the spherical end 440 so that, in the lock position, the locking sheath 450 compresses the spheric l end 440, which compression is enabled by the slots 445 provided in the spherical end. When the spherical end 440 of the socket, portion 435 is compressed, there is an increase in friction. bet.wee.ii the spherical end 440 and ball 430, maki g it more di icult for the first portion 425 to pivot rela ive to the socket portion. When a user wishes to place the locking sheath into he un ock position, w ich may for example he desired after a prosthetic heart, valve has been deployed from t he delivery system, the user retracts the locking sheath 450 proximally . As the locking sheath 450 is retracted, the compression on the spherical end 440 i e iminated, which in turn reduces the friction between the spherical end arid ball 430, Once the locking sheath 450 is in the unlock position, the user may advance the restrictive sheath 410 to the lock position, to look t.he distal sheath 130 in axial alignment with the longitudinal axis of the roxim l sheath 170, enabling the delivery system to be withdrawn from the patient.

[0036] In. an alternative embodiment:, the locking feature can be a chuck similar to a drill chuck (not shown) . i t is
embodiment, the chuck may partially or fully surround the spherical cad 440 of socket portion 3 and may have a lock position and an unlock posi ion. One or more pins or other prat fusions may extend radially inward from the chuck . In the unlock osition; the chuck may surround the spherical end 440 but provide little or no force thereon . To proceed to the lock position, the pins may be advanced radially inward toward the spherical end 440, for example, by rotating the chuck in a first direction. In the lock position, the pins may compress the .'sphe ical end 440 agains the ball 430 with a radially inward force. When a user wishes to move the chuck to the unlock position, which may for example be desired after a prosthetic heart valve has been deployed f om the delivery system, the user may retract the pins away from contact with the .spherical end 440, which may for example be accomplished by rotating the chuck in a direction opposi e the first direction. As the pins retract, the compression on the spherical end 440 is reduced, which in turn reduces the friction between the spherical end and ball 430. O ce the chuck is in the unlock, position, the user may advance the restrictive sheath 410 to the lock position to lock- the distal sheath 130 in axial alignment with the longi udinal axis of the proximal sheath 170, enabling the delivery system to be withdrawn f om the patient ,

For example, stents, occluders, and other devices suitable for implantation in the body may be introduced using embodiments of the del very system described herein,
